essLink.description: In case of concomitant dyspnoea, see
In case of concomitant chest pain, see

essInfo.text: Abnormal heart rhythm is a symptom that can be caused by severe arrhythmias that are only captured intermittently or that are completely harmless in nature but the patient perceives extra beats. Extra beats can produce symptoms, but may not occur at the time of examination. Sudden loss of consciousness without prior symptoms and without suspicion of underlying convulsion disorder may require different and more urgent treatment. At the same time, it is sometimes difficult to distinguish loss of consciousness from arrhythmias from psychosomatically-induced symptoms. Try to anamnestically differentiate loss of consciousness with prodromal symptoms (precursor symptoms) from loss of consciousness that occurs suddenly and without warning and where the patient wakes up on the floor. Always note the time of onset and follow local procedures for further clinical management.

essSymptom.description: After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essInfo.text:
Coughing of blood/haemoptysis should always be taken seriously since underlying disease must be ruled out in cases of repeated bouts of haemoptysis. Haemoptysis can occur in some cases of pulmonary oedema and with pulmonary embolism/pulmonary infarct, but this is relatively uncommon and does not constitute a cardinal symptom. Haemoptysis can also occur with anticoagulation therapy and common, benign cough. For patients with visible bleeding, it is extremely important to check whether anticoagulation therapy is in use or there is a bleeding tendency. Bleeding tendency refers to a known coagulation defect or ongoing anticoagulation treatment (see above). The haemoglobin (Hb) limits are set as guidance and have no scientific basis. They are instead based on how urgent the patient's need for transfusion may be. Vital signs may be deciding factors in cases of really low Hb. With postoperative tonsil bleeding, which is often intermittent, a major and life-threatening condition can occur acutely. It is often the threatened airways that complicate the condition. Fatalities have been reported. A case of postoperative tonsil bleeding can therefore NEVER be prioritised lower than Orange.
If there is no Hb meter prehospital, it must be reported that the assessment has not be completed and must be supplemented.
Bleeds are defined as follows: Small bleed: More saliva than blood Medium bleed: More blood than saliva Large bleed: Blood runs from the nose and/or mouth

essSymptom.description: After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of concomitant infection, see
In case of concomitant heart palpitations, see
In case of concomitant chest pain, see

essInfo.text: +Troponin

Dyspnoea/respiratory distress is one of the most common symptoms of patients seeking or contacting emergency care. Not all conditions have an underlying organic cause of the dyspnoea. The combination VP and ESS therefore plays an important role in handling cases of dyspnoea. It is important to remember that patients with chronic lung diseases often have deviating vital parameters, while those with healthy lungs can have completely normal vital parameters and still have a serious underlying disease. In cases of pulmonary embolism, some patients may be surprisingly unaffected at rest. Acute pulmonary embolism is often combined with some tachycardia, but this is not necessarily particularly pronounced. In some cases, new-onset atrial fibrillation may be associated with pulmonary embolism.
Well's criteria can be used to assess patients with suspected pulmonary embolism. Previous deep vein thrombosis and/or pulmonary embolism are risk factors for pulmonary embolism.
With concomitant chest pain and/or syncope, the symptom dyspnoea must always be considered more serious than without these symptoms.

essSymptom.description: Widespread thoracic sudden pain with vegetative symptoms and/or loss(es) of consciousness
Medical history of loss of consciousness
Concomitant severe chest pain with or without respiratory correlation
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of concomitant dyspnoea, see
In case of concomitant abnormal heart rhythm, see

essInfo.text: + Troponin

Chest pain is the most common reason for contacting emergency care. Chest pain is often described as diffuse and with unclear localisation. When did the chest pain start, was is correlated to breathing, did it come during exertion, cold? Has earlier chest pain acutely changed in nature? Has the chest pain been associated with vegetative symptoms, paleness, cold-sweats, damp skin, and nausea in the patient?
Are there risk factors for ischaemic heart disease, such as previous cardiovascular disease (including intermittent claudication, stroke, TIA), hypertension, smoking, diabetes, hyperlipidaemia, heredity? The existence of one or more risk factors increases the likelihood that acute coronary syndrome exists and strengthens the indication for investigation in case of acute chest pain.
A normal ECG does not rule out acute coronary syndrome. A pathological ECG does not confirm acute coronary syndrome. Check pathological ECG.

essSymptom.description: Widespread thoracic sudden chest pain with vegetative symptoms
Chest pain that comes at rest and/or slight exertion
Chest pain/rib cage pain with concomitant respiratory distress/dyspnoea
Chest pain combined with a history of loss(es) of consciousness
Recent/ongoing chest pain with vegetative symptoms
Ongoing chest pain with signs of ischaemia on ECG
Non-new-onset chest pain with normal ECG
Moderate/mild chest pain in combination with normal ECG
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of concomitant pregnancy, see
In case of concomitant diabetes, see

essInfo.text: ECG + Troponin with abdominal pain above the umbilical plane Pregnancy test if necessary

Abdominal pain is the most common reason for contact and is usually categorised as "surgical" in the emergency care chain. All doctors should be able to handle abdominal pain in primary care. However, the underlying cause can be very varied, with some conditions requiring immediate care measures, but more rarely emergency surgical measures. The onset and occurrence of other symptoms, such as vomiting, haematuria, fever, chills, and diarrhoea, can affect handling and prioritisation. There are also known risk factors that can provide support in the assessment and prioritisation of patients with abdominal pain. These include previous abdominal surgery, known gastrointestinal diseases, abdominal trauma, known aortic aneurysm, peritoneal dialysis (PD patient) and pyelostomy catheters. Do not forget that acute abdominal pain may have a cardiac or metabolic genesis such as with lactic acidosis (sepsis) or ketoacidosis (diabetes).
With low-lying abdominal pain in fertile women, pregnancy or postpartum complications should always be suspected.
Ask whether patient has spent time abroad.

essSymptom.description: Acute onset with ongoing pain and affected general status
Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
Non-reducible, painful resistance in the groin
History of pain and loss of consciousness
Severe/moderate pain in patient with generalised symptoms
Pain in patient with known abdominal aortic aneurysm
Pain in patients with peritoneal dialysis, pyelostomy or gastric bypass
Abdominal pain and repeated bouts of thin diarrhoea
Persistent abdominal pain in a patient that is otherwise unaffected
> 2 bouts of vomiting over past 4 h
Abdominal pain with or without diarrhoea after time abroad
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essSearchPhrase.searchPhrase: Symptoms in the anus and rectum

essLink.description: In case of gynaecological bleeding, see

essInfo.text:
Haematemesis is usually due to bleeding in the ventricle, oesophagus or upper part of the small intestine. Dark/black stool/diarrhoea often means that the bleeding has been going on for some time, while red blood in the stool is usually fresh. Large amounts of blood indicate a major fresh bleed, while small amounts of blood in the stool indicate distal minor bleeding. It is therefore particularly important to specifically ask patients with gastrointestinal bleeding whether there is an increased bleeding tendency.
If there is no capillary blood Hb meter prehospital, it must be reported that the assessment has not be completed and must be supplemented.

essSymptom.description: Ongoing major haematemesis or major rectal bleeding
Medical history of major haematemesis or major rectal bleeding
Ongoing anticoagulation therapy or bleeding tendency
Isolated instances of rectal or oral bleeding
Black stool or blood in the stool
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of pregnancy, see

essInfo.text:
Patients with current (within past 24 hours) repeated seizures are at increased risk of having a further seizure. Adult onset of epilepsy is rare.
An underlying other cause should be suspected. Head trauma? Abuse? Pregnancy – suspected pre-eclampsia Seizures in patients with anticoagulation therapy or bleeding tendency are at increased risk of the seizures being due to intracranial haemorrhaging.

essSymptom.description: Suspected current seizures without previously known epilepsy
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of deficit, see
In case of head trauma, see

essInfo.text:
Ask about head trauma. Dizziness is a common symptom in both younger and older patients. However, the elderly may have difficulty handling ADL in case of sudden dizziness or variation in chronic dizziness. A common cause of sudden dizziness is benign positional vertigo that is exacerbated by head movement and a change in body position. Benign positional vertical is usually rotary in nature. Acute onset refers to sudden onset of dizziness within a time interval of a few hours from arrival.
In case of dizziness in the elderly, it is important to assess the risk of falling and keep the patient under supervision/monitoring during the care period.
Orthostatic test

essSymptom.description: Medical history of loss of consciousness
Isolated bouts of vomiting without other symptoms
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of head trauma, see

essInfo.text:
Stroke is one of the most common issues in patients with neurological symptoms seeking emergency care. With stroke, there are a number of important factors to take into account in relation to prioritisation, diagnosis and treatment. It is particularly important to find the patient early in the course of the disease if cerebral infarction is suspected, as well as find those who may have a bleed to make a decision early in the process. Isolated symptoms like a sudden visual disturbance may be a sign of stroke. Peripheral facial paralysis, difficulty closing the eye Central facial paralysis, can close the eye
Stroke alert is activated according to the local algorithm/memo, which means that a stroke alert can be triggered regardless of medical priority according to RETTS. The priority according to RETTS is based on risk of death or complication in the emergency care chain. Stroke alert is linked to treatment strategy and action.

essSymptom.description: The patient meets the criteria for stroke alert
Patient with intermittent deficit within 7 days
Deficit/stroke that does not meet the criteria for stroke alert
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of infection, see

essInfo.text: ESS 13 is used for involvement in the foot/wrist or proximally to these. The most important measure when treating patients with joint pain is identifying the spread, one or multiple joints, symptom onset and duration. Occurrence of fever/chills and local redness or generalised symptoms. Has the patient undergone prior surgery on the joint or have an implanted prosthesis? With septic arthritis, major joints are usually involved, and it is usually just one joint. Ask about trauma in medical history.

essSymptom.description: Onset <24 h with redness, swollen and tender joint
Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
Surgically implanted material/prosthesis in aching joint
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of haematuria, see
In case of trauma, see
In case of abdominal or flank pain, see
In case of suspected cardiac genesis, see
In case of concomitant neurological deficit, see

essInfo.text:
The most common cause of acute back pain in muscular problem without another organic cause. It is therefore important to at an early stage sort out the patients who need advice on pain management rather than supplementary investigation. Those with an obvious urgent problem development should be investigated and treated in a different manner.
In case of repeated and prolonged pain in an otherwise unaffected patient who has no signs and symptoms according to ESS 14, a care level other than the emergency department can usually be used.
New-onset neurological deficit refers to a motor and/or sensory deficit in the extremity (this algorithm) that has appeared or accentuated, or that was not found as a chronic previously-investigated condition.
ECG with thoracic back pain

essSymptom.description: Sudden onset with ongoing pain and generalised symptoms
Thoracic sudden pain with vegetative symptoms (cold sweats, nausea) or loss of consciousness
Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
Thoracic sudden pain without vegetative symptoms
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of infection, see

essInfo.text:
Acute pain in the extremity without prior trauma can be a vascular disorder. In patients with known or unknown atrial fibrillation, cardiac embolisms may occlude extremity vessels. In case of acute onset of cold extremity, there should always be contact with a vascular surgeon (this must be done without delay – the extremity is threatened!!).
Some haematological disorders are also associated with an increased risk of thromboembolism, as are women who are pregnant, have recently given birth, or are undergoing hormone therapy.
In case of chills and severe pain, necrotising fasciitis should be suspected, with the patient always being rated as orange until the diagnosis has been ruled out. These conditions are associated with high mortality (emergency care immediately!!). In case of suspicion, perform blood culture immediately.
Well's criteria can be used to assess patients with suspected DVT.

essSymptom.description: Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essPreaction.description: Serum haemoglobin g/L in case of haematuria

essLink.description: In case of fever and infection, consider
In case of abdominal pain, see

essInfo.text:
The causes underlying painful urination are many. Ask about previous symptoms of a similar character. Macroscopic haematuria may have different degrees of acuteness, but is always grounds for an investigation decision, which in most cases may take place at an outpatient clinic.
Percutaneous urinary catheter involves an increased risk of infection for the patient. In case of complications, these patients should be treated according to local procedure.

essSymptom.description: Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
Macroscopic haematuria with anticoagulation therapy or bleeding tendency
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essInfo.text: Scrotal pain can be caused by epididymitis, which can occur at any age but is rare before puberty. Testicular torsion usually affects boys and young men, and is characterised by sudden or intermittent onset of one-sided scrotal pain with swelling. Immediate contact with Urology is important/mandatory is testicular torsion is suspected. In older men, the pain may be caused by scrotal hernia.

essSymptom.description: Sudden onset and/or intermittent scrotal pain < 48 hours
Trauma to the scrotum and severe pain/oedema
Swelling and/or bleeding in the area
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of deficit, see
In case of head trauma, see

essInfo.text:
Thunderclap headache is a cardinal symptom of subarachnoid haemorrhage. It may be a minor so-called warning bleed and should be taken very seriously. Thunderclap headache means that the headache comes suddenly. In such patients, subarachnoid haemorrhage should always be suspected and ruled out.
Meningism is defined as the patient having headache, generalised symptoms, and reflexive neck stiffness during passive (examiner bends the head forwards) flexion in the neck.
High blood pressure is not an acute condition, but should be handled according to local procedures.

essSymptom.description: Medical history of suspected neurological deficit
Repeated vomiting that debuted at the same time
Medical history of loss of consciousness
Systolic blood pressure >240 and/or diastolic blood pressure >140 mmHG (repeated measurements)
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of dizziness, see
In case of suspected cardiac genesis, see

essInfo.text:
Ask about trauma in medical history. Definition of loss of consciousness: fainting or syncope, i.e. where loss of consciousness is reported by the patient or a relative/bystander.
Fainting is a very common symptom and can be assessed solely with medical history and a clinical status to determine if there is an underlying disease. Sudden loss of consciousness without prior symptoms and without suspicion of convulsion disorder may need a higher priority. At the same time, it is sometimes difficult to distinguish loss of consciousness from arrhythmias from psychosomatic symptoms.
Try to anamnestically differentiate loss of consciousness with prodromal symptoms (precursor symptoms) from loss of consciousness where the patient suddenly collapses and wakes up on the floor.
Patients who have precursor symptoms prior to fainting and remember everything before and after usually have only benign fainting.
Orthostatic test ECG

essSymptom.description: One bout of loss of consciousness
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of abdominal pain, see

essInfo.text:
This algorithm/ESS differs from Abdominal pain ESS 6 in that it is intended to capture problems from the retroperitoneal organs of women. It is important to bear in mind that here, an unborn child in a pregnant woman must be assessed a priority in addition to the actual patient. As a result, RETTS with this algorithm is associated with a greater risk of overtriage than algorithm no. 6.
For a pregnant woman with cramps NOS, pre-eclampsia should be suspected.
Follow local procedures regarding referral to Delivery or Gynaecology.
Bleeds are defined as follows: Major bleed – bleeding or clotting through two large sanitary towels/hour for more than two hours without signs of decreasing. Moderate bleed – heavier than heavy menstruation

essSymptom.description: Sudden onset with ongoing pain in patient with generalised symptoms
Abdominal pain that comes at intervals
Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
Current seizures without previously known epilepsy in pregnant patient
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of poisoning, see
In case of eye injury, see
In case of ear injury, see

essInfo.text:
In case of injury to the head/neck, it is important to ask about anticoagulation therapy or bleeding tendency.
Pulsating bleeding refer s to suspected arterial haemorrhage in the region. Injuries to the face can sometimes be combined with eye injury and facial fracture. Suspicion of such automatically gives higher priority to doctor.
Bleeding from the ear canal, haematoma behind the ear (Battle's sign) or haematoma around the eyes ("panda eyes" haematoma) can be associated with fracture at the base of the skull. Severe swelling in the head/neck region may be associated with increased risk of the airways being affected and could lead to difficulties swallowing. Patient with motor restlessness should be a note of caution.
If commotio cerebri/concussion is suspected, see local process measures.

essSymptom.description: Severe and increasing swelling in the region
Loss of consciousness/amnesia in connection with injury
Assault may not be given priority lower than yellow
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of penetrating trauma, see

essInfo.text: With this type of injury, a decision must always be made as to whether the special trauma algorithm should be used (see ESS 38).

essSymptom.description: Breathing-correlated thoracic pain with vegetative symptoms
Increasing abdominal pain and/or abdominal circumference
Assault may not be given priority lower than yellow
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of RED priority, see

essInfo.text:
Reduced distal status is where the pulse and/or sensation has been affected away from the injury.
Compartment syndrome arises when an arm muscle swells so much that the pressure affects muscle, blood flow and nerves. It can also occur if a plaster cast is too tight, causing excess pressure on the tissue. Must be treated urgently to avoid permanent injury.
All fractures without malposition/open fracture fall under suspected fracture and are thus given priority GREEN.

essSymptom.description: Amputation in or proximal to the wrist
At least 2 fractures on long bones
Fracture with malposition/open fracture proximal to the wrist
Signs of infection and pain during flexion/extension
Pain and signs of compartment syndrome
Luxation in or proximal to the wrist
Assault may have priority YELOOW at the lowest
Malposition/open fracture distal to the wrist
Suspected luxation distal to the wrist
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of RED priority, see

essInfo.text: Reduced distal status is where the pulse and/or sensation has been affected distal to the injury. Compartment syndrome arises when a leg muscle swells so much that the pressure affects muscles, blood flow and nerves. It can also occur if a plaster cast is too tight, causing excess pressure on the tissue. Must be treated urgently to avoid permanent injury.

essSymptom.description: Amputation in or proximal to the ankle
At least 2 fractures on long bones
Fracture with malposition/open fracture proximal to the foot
Signs of infection and pain during flexion/extension
Suspected femoral fracture, including hip fracture
Pain and signs of compartment syndrome
Fracture with malposition distal to the ankle
Suspected fracture in ankle or proximal to the ankle
Suspected luxation in ankle or proximal to the ankle
Assault may have the lowest yellow priority
Suspected fracture distal to the ankle
Suspected luxation distal to the ankle
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of RED priority, see

essInfo.text:
In case of chemical accidents, take into account the risk of contamination to personnel and equipment. Decision on decontamination is made prehospital. In case of burns and smoke inhalation, it is important to check COHb in the blood. POX in such patients may show a normal value despite the patient having hypoxia. Symptoms in cases of smoke inhalation that may be considered serious are CNS symptoms (previous loss of consciousness) or severe coughing, dyspnoea.
In this context, high voltage refers to anything over standard household voltage 230 V. Patients exposed to household voltage may need follow-up in relation to late complications (nerve damage, etc.). In case of radiation injury, contact a local or regional expert. Severe cooling (exposure) is handled via vital parameter E and other VP.
1% is like the patient's palm

essSymptom.description: Burn/corrosion injury to the face/neck with threat of obstructed airway
Inhalation injury from chemical content and/or hot smoke from fire
Chemical/corrosion injury from potentially life-threatening substance on skin or per os
Loss of consciousness in medical history
Lighting strike in patient's immediate vicinity
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of dominant neurology and suspected stroke, see
In case of postoperative status, see

essInfo.text: Suspected or known corrosion injury in the eye should be flushed. Follow local memo/procedures

essSymptom.description: Corrosion injury or suspected corrosion injury
Infected eye with temperature and pain
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essInfo.text:
Observations: If no trauma alert criteria are met, but there are one or more observations, this should give rise to contact with the on-call doctor to prioritise treatment of the patient, adapt the need for alert, or correct the alert level. • Gradual deterioration of patient with suspected serious injury • Increased risk of bleeding (anticoagulants) • Age <5 years or >60 years • Serious underlying disease • Hypothermia <35°C • Under influence of drugs • Pregnant
Process measure at hospital: The final trauma level assessment is always conducted at hospital for RED/Level 1 and ORANGE/Level 2 priority. Only alert level for trauma team activation is specified pre hospital.
The patient can be given yellow priority if, after examination, a licensed healthcare professional determines that the patient is not red or orange according to RETTS. If activated, the trauma alert can be downgraded to green priority prehospital if the patient has been examined by a licensed healthcare professional and has been found to be completely injury-free and asymptomatic. It is advisable for YELLOW priority to always be examined by a hospital/medical facility. The decision is made by a licensed healthcare professional and documented.

This algorithm follows the national guidelines for Level 1 or Level 2 trauma alert. Use RETTS trauma journal (available from www.predicare.se)
One or more criteria in the RED box leads to alert LEVEL 1 = RED trauma alert level according to ESS 38 One or more criteria in ORANGE priority leads to alert LEVEL 2. Patients who lack clear or suspected criteria for RED priority become ORANGE = Level 2, even if no appropriate criterion is found in the ORANGE box.

essSymptom.description: Blood pressure < 90 mmHg or no palpable radial pulse
Penetrating force to the head, neck or trunk, extremity above the elbow/knee
Severe pain in pelvis/suspected pelvic fracture
The patient may be given yellow priority if examination shows that the condition can be handled with another ESS
The patient may be given green priority if none of the above are met.
There is no blue priority in this ESS

essInfo.text:
In case known suicide attempt or suspected suicide attempt, special monitoring must be considered. Always consider the need for contact with a social welfare officer and/or follow-up in outpatient care. Consider whether report under Care of Alcoholics and Drug Abusers Act is required in case of abuse.
In case of mushroom poisoning (mycetism), ask the patient about likely type of mushroom and ask relatives (if possible) to bring in any remains to show someone with expertise in fungi within the healthcare system. It is a good idea to consult the mushroom book the patient used when picking them. Note the exact time the mushroom/meal was ingested.
Always specify the time of ingestion of toxic substance(s).
Poisons Information Centre 08-331231. In urgent cases, call 112 and request Poisons Information Centre, www.giftinfo.se (login: giftinfo, password: intox)

essSymptom.description: Ingestion of substance for purpose of suicide
Ingestion of unknown substance or low dose of known substance
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of allergic reaction to animal, see

essInfo.text: Poisons Information Centre: 08-331231. In urgent cases, call 112 and request Poisons Information Centre, www.giftinfo.se (login: giftinfo, password: intox)

essSymptom.description: Bites from animal with potential toxic risk.
Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
Stings/bites in throat or oral cavity
Previous history of serious allergic reaction from bites or stings
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essInfo.text:
Physical abuse and/or sexual violence should always be taken very seriously. In many cases, there are often other problems with both the patient and the perpetrator. Alcohol and drugs are not uncommon. It is therefore particularly important to handle the patient with some intensity since there may be things that affect risk and progress that do not come to light during the first attempt at obtaining a clinical picture.
Otherwise, abuse is handled in the ESS that applies to the location of the classified injury.
Always offer contact with a social welfare officer. Take photos if necessary; suggest that a police report be filed. Follow local memo for forensic medical report.

essSymptom.description: Physical abuse cannot be given a priority lower than YELLOW

essLink.description: In case of animal bite/sting without allergic reaction, see

essInfo.text:
Anaphylactic reactions, regardless of reason, are usually divided into different phases.
Initial phase: Within a few minutes to one hour after contact with the triggering agent. The symptoms are often itching on the palms, reddening and cutaneous symptoms and itching in the throat.
Progress phase: More general symptoms with urticaria, angioedema, tachycardia, abdominal pain (other gastrointestinal symptoms may also occur).
Shock phase: Altered consciousness, hypotension and loss of circulation.
Allergy is a dynamic process and may be mild initially but develop into a serious condition. For this reason, supervision and re-evaluation are extra-important for patients with allergic reaction.
Petechial rash is no special disease. It is a name given to rashes due to small pinpoint bleeds in the skin or in the mucous membranes (e.g. in the mouth). Depending on the age of the rash, they can be more or less red, blue, purple or brownish.
Poisons Information Centre: 08-331231. In urgent cases, call 112 and request Poisons Information Centre, www.giftinfo.se (login: giftinfo, password: intox)

essSymptom.description: After examination, no immediate need for emergency care
Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of haemoptysis or bleeding in the throat region, see

essInfo.text:
Button cell batteries and/or magnets are found in toys and are sometimes swallowed mainly by children. The battery creates a weak current between the - and + poles, which could damage the mucous membrane and tissue where the magnets/poles are pulled towards each other. It is important for the battery or magnets to be removed quickly with gastroscopy to prevent oesophageal injury or injury to other parts of the gastrointestinal tract.
Pharyngitis/laryngitis is more common in adults, while children get what is called pseudocroup (laryngitis subglottica) and sometimes epiglottitis, which is a more serious condition. Viral infection is most common. It is important to rule out epiglottitis and stridor captured directly with RETTS VP.

essSymptom.description: Serious threat of obstructed airway, see VP
Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
Foreign body suspected of ending up on the lower/rear airways
Swallowed button cell battery or magnets
Foreign body stuck in the nose
Difficulties swallowing, but ability to swallow saliva
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of suspected infection and joint involvement, see

essInfo.text:
Symptoms/signs of infection that seem banal may deteriorate and affect vital parameters. Sepsis (bacterial infection) is a very serious and potentially life-threatening condition. It is most commonly originates from the airways, urinary tract, wound or abdominal organs.
Early diagnosis of sepsis and initiation of antibiotics are crucial for the patient's prognosis. Signs of infection in combination with severe local pain may be a sign of invasive streptococcal infection, which is serious.
Petechiae in the skin and mucous membranes is a serious sign and is due to small pinpoint bleeds in the skin or in the mucous membranes (e.g. in the mouth). Depending on the age of the rash, they can be more or less red, blue, purple or brownish. Meningism is defined as the patient having headache, generalised symptoms, and reflexive neck stiffness during passive (examiner bends the head forwards) flexion in the neck.
Immunosuppressed patients (cytostatics, cortisone or other immunosuppressive treatment or known immunodeficiency) with signs of infection are at increased risk of serious infection. Surgically implanted materials, such as shunt catheters, peritoneal dialysis catheters and mechanical flaps, always involve an increased risk of serious infection. Bear in mind that the patient may have taken fever-reducing drugs, which affect the measurement.
SIRS criteria: This ESS is supplemented with the internationally used and evaluated SIRS criteria, and is used as a supplement to RETTS when the diagnosis SEPSIS has the highest probability Respiratory rate: >20/min or < 4 kPa pCO2 Heart rate: >90/min Temp: >38°C <36°C LKCS: > 12 or < 4
At least 2 criteria must be met for SIRS to be considered to exist. An outcome in SIRS does not affect the priority level in RETTS. It should instead be used as diagnostic support and the RETTS decision support has given its priority level.

essSymptom.description: Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
Patient with fever >38.5°C + history of surgically implanted material
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essInfo.text:
Patients with hyperglycaemia (hyperosmolar state) or diabetic ketoacidosis may exhibit varying symptoms and signs. Other underlying diagnoses are therefore sometimes suspected initially. Cerebral, circulatory, respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms are common.
Patients with new-onset diabetes and/or concomitant ketoacidosis often experience abdominal pain that sometimes causes the patient to be primarily sorted to Surgery. Venous blood gas with blood lactate is an important support in treatment.
Hypoglycaemia is usually associated with known diabetes mellitus. Symptoms often debut quickly and sometimes with vegetative, psychiatric and/or other CNS symptoms. Quick diagnosis and prompt action are important. If there is no effect from treatment with glucose, differential diagnosis should be considered.
Always check whether patients with hypoglycaemia have an insulin pump. If so, it should be removed/switched off.

essSymptom.description: Overdose of insulin or oral antidiabetics
Suspected insulin overdose, but normal P-glucose
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essLink.description: In case of infection, see

essInfo.text:
ESS 51 is used for both primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency. Immunosuppressed patients on cytostatics, cortisone or other newer immunosuppression drugs are handled under the symptoms that the patient exhibits.
Patients with adrenal insufficiency are particularly sensitive to disease conditions such as fever, gastroenteritis and hypovolaemia. Their normal defence in the form of adrenal cortex activation is eliminated or impaired. Patients with adrenal insufficiency are often on substitution, which in connection with disease can usually be adjusted upwards according to a schedule the patient manages themselves. This may sometimes be insufficient, which means that the patient must be treated with high priority since the condition can quickly develop into a life-threatening condition with circulatory shock.
In society, there is a growing number of patients who for various reasons are undergoing immunosuppressive treatment. It is important to document at the time of the patient's arrival whether immunosuppression is in use and if necessary take the actions defined at the hospital the patient is visiting.

essSymptom.description: Failure to take or maintain the prescribed dose of cortisone
Medical history of chills and/or fever
Infection history, but took cortisone as prescribed
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essInfo.text:
ESS 53 is an unspecific ESS and should not be routinely used in emergency care. There are potentially serious underlying causes, e.g. psychiatry, physical abuse, social conditions, infection, injury NOS, poisoning, etc., that can cause unspecific symptoms. This patient group is often older and/or has difficulty reporting their symptoms.
Patients who seek care with high blood pressure are often referral patients. High or low blood pressure is a common examination finding in the emergency care chain. One or a small number of high measurements are NOT NECESSARILY hypertension. They may be physiological if the patient has a high cardiac output and vasoconstriction due to stress escalation. However, if blood pressure is associated with cerebral symptoms and/or cardiac symptoms, high blood pressure should be assessed as a possible alarm sign and be handled accordingly. If a urine dip shows no proteinuria in the patient, then the high blood pressure is probably temporary. If malignant hypertension (an uncommon condition) is suspected, the patient should be treated more quickly and always be admitted to hospital. Malignant hypertension is always associated with proteinuria, grade 3 hypertensive retinopathy, and often hypertensive encephalopathy (affected sensorium).
Tests according to RETTS ESS 70

essSymptom.description: Acute confusion and SBP >240 mmHg and DBP >140 mmHg
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essSearchPhrase.searchPhrase: Test result algorithm (test results via referral)

essLink.description: Patient comes in for secondary assessment, see

essInfo.text: ESS 70 is intended to meet the need in RETTS for the user to know which tests (see process measures) are recommended within each priority level. If RETTS Local is used, the user organisation determines if and which tests are to be used for each individual patient. In emergency care, there is a need along with increased access to bedside analyses. This places higher demands on rapid assessment and action since some analyses have a stronger direct predictive value than others. If patients who come into the emergency department with a visit reason involving one or more issues, a referral sometimes come from primary care, urgent care centres and the like. In such cases, both ESS 70 and ESS 75 can be used for secondary assessment of condition or test results.
Local process measures are developed and used locally.

essSymptom.description: PT/INR >2.5 for patient without anticoagulation therapy
S-paracetamol micromol/L >reference for antidote treatment www.internetmedicin.se
Troponin microgram/L >local limit for myocardial infarction/ACS

essProcessaction.description: Venous blood gas, incl. blood lactate
Complete blood count, Hb, LKCS, PLTs
Venous blood gas, incl. blood lactate
Complete blood count Hb, LKCS, PLTs
Venous blood gas, incl. blood lactate

No tests recommended according to RETTS

essInfo.text:
A malpositioned cast can cause both discomfort and injury. Any complaints the patient makes of pain or discomfort should always be taken seriously. Increasing pain should not be ignored, but rather carefully examined. Complications can developed in a short period of time. There is often reason to remove the case. Complications include pressure sores, ulceration, vascular injury and nerve damage.
If there are signs of disrupted circulation, see orange criteria, the cast must be removed immediately. If the patient only has swelling or haematoma, this may sometimes be normal after the injury. In addition, unstable fractures may come out of position if the cast is removed. For this reason, patients with repositioned fractures should generally be assessed by a doctor before cast removal.
Compartment syndrome can arise due to internal swelling after trauma (e.g. fracture, bleeding or torn muscle), external compression (e.g. plaster treatment) or due to a burn injury. The increased pressure leads to reduced blood supply to the extremities and can lead to permanent and severe muscle damage within a few hours. The symptoms are often severe pain, reduced muscle strength, decreased feeling, reduced colour and temperature and, above all, pain during passive movement. Note that normal pulsations do not rule out compartment syndrome!

essSymptom.description: Severe pain, signs/symptoms of compartment syndrome
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essInfo.text:
Surgical complications can be local complications, such as wound rupture, infection or bleeding. They can also be more general complications like DVT, UTI, pneumonia, sepsis. However, these are best handled with another algorithm, such as ESS 15 or ESS 47.
If there is a bandage or cast covering a surgical site, it should always be removed if complication is suspected.
Compartment syndrome can arise due to internal swelling after trauma (e.g. fracture, bleeding or torn muscle), external compression (e.g. plaster treatment) or due to a burn injury. The increased pressure leads to reduced blood supply to the extremities and can lead to permanent and severe muscle damage within a few hours. The symptoms are often severe pain, reduced muscle strength, decreased feeling, reduced colour and temperature and pain during passive movement. Note that normal pulsations do not rule out compartment syndrome!
In case of bleeding, patients with recent throat surgery can quickly develop compression of the trachea with subsequent airway obstruction.

essSymptom.description: Sudden onset with ongoing pain in patient with vegetative symptoms
Fever >38.5°C and chills now or before arrival
Procedure that can increase the risk of threatened airways
Severe/moderate pain in patient with vegetative symptoms
Moderate pain with signs of local infection
After examination, no immediate need for emergency care

essInfo.text:
This ESS should be used for patients who have been assessed by another care provider and where there is a medical need for assessment by another care provider.
Form an opinion on data presented: use current ESS and follow RETTS. In case of pathological radiology results, supplement with local preparations. In case of jaundice skin or eyes, take liver status according to local procedure.
The process measures are developed locally for and by each organisation holding a RETTS licence. These adaptations are done within the individual organisation.

essSymptom.description: No current need for emergency care

essProcessaction.description: Supplement sample collection if necessary; see ESS 70
